newsitem.title: INDIA: Honda seeks 18 pct of India premium cars.
newsitem.headline: Honda seeks 18 pct of India premium cars.

text.p: The Indian unit of Japan's Honda Motor Co said on Friday it was hopeful its "City" model, which will hit the Indian market in December, will capture nearly 18 percent of the country's premium car market.

"The total premium car market is around 200,000 annually. We are aiming at a market share of around 17-18 percent," Siddharth Shriram, chairman of Honda Siel Cars India Ltd, told Reuters at the end of a news conference to unveil the model.
HSCI is a joint venture between Honda Motor Co and India's Siel Ltd.

"The company (HSCI) plans to sell 4,000 units in the first four months with the number increasing to 30,000 units by the year 1999-2000," said Teruo Fujisaki, president and chief executive officer of Honda Siel.
He said the car will be manufactured at HSCI's new plant at Noida on the outskirts of Delhi. The installed capacity of the plant was around 30,000 cars a year.

Fujisaki said the City car had been developed after a detailed study to suit the "unique needs and conditions of the Indian market, taking into account the road conditions, climatic factors, driving habits and traffic conditions."
He said locally-supplied components would comprise 50 percent at the beginning but would gradually rise to 75 percent by the year 2000/01.

Honda holds 90 percent in Honda Siel and India's Siel Ltd has 10 percent. But this is a temporary arrangement to help cash-strapped Siel, which has the option to buy back 30 percent by the end of October 1998, company officials said.
"In October 1998, it would again be 40-60," Shriram said.
Fujisaki said the joint venture envisaged investment of 8.5 billion rupees ($237 million) over the next six or seven years.
Honda is the latest among several world car majors entering India under an economic reform programme initiated in 1991, which opened up the market to foreign investors.

Among the premium models that Honda's City would compete with are Daewoo Motor Corp's Cielo, General Motors' Opel Astra and the Esteem, produced by Maruti Udyog Ltd's Esteem, a joint venture between the Indian government and Suzuki Motor Corp.
"Esteem, Cielo, Opel Astra and DCM Daewoo will be our natural competitors," Shriram said.
"We are currently assisting seven Japanese companies to set up units, mostly joint ventures, in India who will be supplying parts and equipments for the "City" model," Shriram said.
Honda Siel has an authorised capital of 1.8 billion rupees ($50.2 million), which is expected to be paid up by March, 1997. ($1 = 35.8 rupees)
